content: How can I help you today?
I've been having trouble sleeping lately. I feel like there's so much on my mind, especially with work, and it's really affecting me. I'm not sure how to deal with it.
It sounds like you've been carrying a lot with work and stress, and it's impacting your sleep. That must feel overwhelming at times. What’s been on your mind the most when it comes to work?

I keep worrying about getting fired. Things at work have been stressful, and I feel like layoffs might be coming. I’m worried I’ll be one of the first to go, and I don’t know what I’d do if that happened. It’s keeping me up at night.

It sounds like the fear of losing your job and uncertainty about what might happen next has been weighing heavily on you. That kind of stress can make it hard to relax, especially at night. How have you been handling these worries so far?

Honestly, not very well. I just end up overthinking everything, and I’ll grab my phone to distract myself, but then that just adds more thoughts to my head. I know it’s not helping, but I feel stuck in this cycle.

It sounds like you're caught in a loop of stress and trying to find ways to escape it, even though those distractions might not be giving you the relief you’re hoping for. It’s understandable to feel stuck in that cycle. What matters most to you when it comes to breaking free from this?

I guess what matters most is just being able to sleep again and not feel so drained all the time. I want to be present for my family and not constantly consumed by work stress. I just don’t know where to start.

Feeling drained and wanting to be fully present for your family means you deeply value the connection you have with them. Wanting to sleep better shows how much you're longing for balance in your life. Starting can feel overwhelming—what do you think might help you take even the smallest step toward easing that stress?

I’m not really sure, to be honest. Maybe I could try putting my phone down earlier, but that feels really hard since it's the only thing that distracts me. I don’t know if there’s anything else I can do right now.

You're considering putting your phone down earlier, even though that feels challenging because it helps distract you. That’s an important insight. Finding other ways to manage your stress or create a calming routine might be worth exploring, but you don’t have to figure it all out at once. What’s something small and manageable you feel you could try without it feeling overwhelming?

I don't know... Maybe I could try setting a timer on my phone to remind myself to stop using it at a certain time. Or I could try reading a book instead, but honestly, I'm not sure if I'd stick with it. All of this feels easier said than done.

You’re brainstorming some thoughtful options, like setting a timer or reading to unwind, even though you’re unsure how committed you might be right now. It seems like you’re recognizing small ways to shift your habits, even if they feel challenging. What do you think might make it easier to give one of these a try?

I guess if I had some sort of plan or routine to follow, it could help me feel more motivated. Maybe if I got my partner involved or had a specific book ready, it wouldn't feel as hard to stick to it. But I'm still not totally sure—I just don’t want to feel like I’m failing if I can’t do it perfectly.

Having a plan, involving your partner, or choosing a specific book could make the idea more approachable and give you the support to stay motivated. It sounds like you value progress over perfection and don’t want added pressure. If you gave yourself permission to take small steps without needing them to be perfect, how might that feel for you?

If I could focus on small steps, I guess it might make it feel less overwhelming. Maybe I can try setting the timer and just see how that goes for a couple of nights—kind of experiment with it. If it doesn’t work out perfectly, I’ll try not to beat myself up over it.

That sounds like a good starting point—giving yourself room to experiment and approaching it with self-kindness. You've made an important step by considering manageable actions and adjusting your expectations. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before thinking about how you might move forward?
I think that's all for now. Thanks for listening and helping me talk through this. I'll try giving the timer idea a go and see how I manage.
